topic: Self-Sabotage as a Weapon in Journaling

dialog.text: Why do I keep sabotaging my journaling, even when I want to grow?
Because your brain loves easy wins; we’ll reframe sabotage so it targets the right enemy.
Step 1 says identify what actually needs sabotaging. How do I pick 2-3 things that really hold me back?
Make a short list of the big drains: bad habits, limiting beliefs, and energy leaks—then pick the two that sting the most.
Okay, I’ve got scrolling, perfectionism, and 'I’m not enough.'
Step 2 uses sabotage against them by making them harder, more annoying, or turning them into tiny anti-goals.
Examples: grayscale your phone to make scrolling feel pointless; post the worst, shortest journal entry in 5 minutes; or set a tiny writing sprint to prove you can show up.
Step 3 is to keep sabotaging the right things until you win—destroy patterns that keep you stuck.
Got it. What’s something I can start today?
Pick one target and commit: 1) make the hardest habit harder; 2) create tiny, actionable challenges; 3) prove a negative belief wrong with a quick test.
I’ll start by writing the worst, shortest journal entry in 5 minutes.
Perfect. Now tell the audience: what’s the first thing you’ll sabotage today? Comment below with your target and why.
